I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $12,000,000 (in sum equivalent) to Anglesey Food Foreign Enterprise LLC (Korzinka) for 
the Korzinka COVID-19 Food Retail Supply Chain Support Project in Uzbekistan. 
 
2.  The proceeds of debt financing will provide essential liquidity to Korzinka, a company 
engaged  in  food  retailing,  to  enhance  resilience  to  the  disruptive  economic  effects  of  the 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, sustain food security, support Korzinka’s growth, and 
preserve the livelihoods of more than 4,400 employees and more than 1,200 farm workers.1 The 
project will help Korzinka build inventory buffers (for existing and new supermarkets) of essential 
food products including wheat, buckwheat, and potatoes to mitigate the risk of COVID-19-related 
supply disruptions; support faster payments to risk-averse suppliers; and fund COVID-19-related 
operating expenditures including masks, sanitization, personal protective equipment, testing, and 
staff quarantining costs. Furthermore, ADB will help raise Korzinka’s equal opportunity standards 
in the food retail industry and improve the inclusion of women in the workforce.  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
 
1.  Project Identification 
 
3.  COVID-19 impact on the economy of Uzbekistan. Although Uzbekistan’s economy 
expanded in 2020, the pandemic slowed growth to 1.7% after an average of 5.5% during 2016–
2019 (forecast of 4.0% in 2021).2 In early 2020, the Government of Uzbekistan imposed a strict 
lockdown.3 While these restrictions have been mostly relaxed, the emergence of new COVID-19 
variants has led to an increase in cases, which peaked in July–August 2021 with 800–1,000 cases 
per day and decreased to around 400 cases in October 2021.4 The effects of the pandemic, 
restrictions, and economic fallout is disproportionately felt by the most vulnerable communities, 
including in rural areas.5 Unemployment rose from 9.0% to 11.1% during 2019–2020 and the 
number of people living in poverty rose to around 3 million (9.0% of 34 million), an additional 
500,000 people compared with the precrisis forecast (7.4%). During the initial lockdown in 2020, 
traditional bazaars were closed while modern retail continued.6 Thus, modern retail served as an 
important sales channel for farmers who faced increasing sales risks and uncertain incomes. 
Hence, Korzinka is centrally positioned to support weaker supply chain partners including farmers 
through liquidity support to sustain operations and provide relative certainty of future sales.  
 
4.  Food security in Uzbekistan. During the pandemic, Uzbekistan’s food imports increased 
from 9.3% as a share of imports in 2019 to 11.2% in 2020.7 Adding to this, Uzbekistan’s trading 
partners restricted food trade. The Russian Federation banned exports of wheat (in May–June

2020) and buckwheat (in June–August 2021) while Kazakhstan imposed a wheat export quota 
(for 2020) and Ukraine limited sunflower oil exports (2020 to mid-2021).8 Korzinka responded by 
sourcing from local processors, who increased production of key staples such as flour and 
vegetable oils.9 In addition, the company drew on the government’s strategic food reserves of 
buckwheat and potatoes.10 Although some restrictions have been phased out, the risk of further 
supply shocks remains. The business environment continues to be marred by uncertainties 
across the supply chain, including raw material shortages, high freight costs, risks of border 
closures, and risk aversion of suppliers demanding faster repayments. These factors all lead to 
increased costs of doing business and higher working capital needs. 
 
5.  Importance of the agriculture sector in Uzbekistan. Agriculture is the largest sector 
and largest employer in Uzbekistan’s economy. In 2019, agriculture contributed to 28% of gross 
domestic product while employing 27% of the labor force (3.7 million people). The sector is divided 
into large commercial farms with an average size of around 100.0 hectares employing 40% of 
sector workers, and smallholder farms of around 0.3 hectares employing around 60% of sector 
workers. Agricultural output has been dominated by wheat and cotton; however, the Government 
of Uzbekistan is supporting farm diversification into higher value and labor-intensive horticulture. 
In 2020, the closing of bazaars posed a serious threat to the livelihoods of smallholder farmers in 
rural areas, who account for around 80% of Uzbekistan’s poor.11 As bazaars were closed, farmers 
faced liquidity problems as they were unable to sell their produce. Korzinka increased sourcing 
directly from farmers and accelerated payments to farmers to support their operations and sustain 
the supply of essential produce, thereby preserving livelihoods. 
 
6.  Project selection. Korzinka is a suitable candidate for ADB’s indirect COVID-19 response 
as the company (i) is affected by COVID-19-related uncertainty whereby suppliers demand faster 
repayments to sustain and increase supplies; (ii) aims to build an interim inventory buffer of food 
products  to  mitigate  the  risk  of  COVID-19-related  supply  shocks  (for  new  and  existing 
supermarket stores); (iii) needs to fund incremental operational expenditures including masks, 
sanitization supplies, and personal protective equipment for staff; (iv) requires ADB’s medium-
term financing that is unavailable from local banks; (v) will help support food security in Uzbekistan 
as a key supplier of staples, serving more than 710,000 households (11% of the population) while 
also supporting the livelihoods of more than 4,400 employees and more than 1,200 farm workers; 
and (vi) is willing to partner with ADB to enhance its gender equality standards. 
 
2.  Project Design  
  
7.  One ADB approach. The project has been developed in close collaboration between the 
Private Sector Operations Department and the Central and West Asia Regional Department. The 
Uzbekistan Resident Mission has been instrumental in identifying and cultivating the relationship 
with the company since 2019 and facilitated due diligence. In addition, the project is expected to 
have synergies with two ongoing sovereign projects on horticulture value chain development.12

3 
Liquidity for working capital and supporting rural livelihoods. Korzinka has increased direct 
sourcing of horticulture produce from local farms. As traditional bazaars closed, Korzinka served 
as an alternate sales channel to help sustain farmers’ operations through the COVID-19 crisis. 
While the company sourced from 137 farms in 2020, this number is expected to reach 176 in 
2021, of which two-thirds are smallholder farms (operating less than 2 hectares). [Redacted] 
Korzinka’s suppliers are operating at their exposure limits. In addition, given the uncertainties due 
to the COVID-19 environment, suppliers have become risk averse such that they demand faster 
repayments. Thus, Korzinka plans to temporarily reduce the average payable days [Redacted]. 
This will support suppliers in meeting Korzinka’s growing demand during this uncertain period 
[Redacted].  
 
8.  Strengthen food security, food safety, and nutrition. The grocery retail market is 
shifting from traditional bazaars towards modern retail. Consumers benefit from product variety, 
safer and better-quality food products, and an increased level of hygiene, which is especially 
important in the COVID-19 context.13 As Uzbekistan’s largest modern grocery retail firm, Korzinka 
contributes to food security as it serves more than 11% of households. Korzinka is certified ISO 
9001 and ISO 22000, ensuring the highest product quality, food safety, and hygiene.14 Korzinka’s 
food products include essential food items such as fruit and vegetables, groceries, baked and 
prepared  food,  beverages,  meat,  and  dairy  products.  At  the  onset  of  the  pandemic,  the 
Government  of  Uzbekistan  removed  import  duties  on  essential  food  staples  (flour,  pasta, 
vegetable oils) and required retailers to temporarily increase stocks of these products.15 To 
mitigate  the  risk  of  further  supply  disruptions,  Korzinka  plans  to  build  an  inventory  buffer 
[Redacted].  
 
9.  Preserve livelihoods of farmers and workers. About 65% of purchases are sourced 
locally,  including  fruit  and  vegetables  (e.g.,  tomatoes,  apples,  potatoes,  onions)  and  dairy 
products (milk, yoghurt), which directly supports the local economy and rural farmers. Through its 
sourcing, Korzinka impacts the livelihoods of over 1,200 farmers and farm workers. Climate 
change impact on the project is low as Korzinka has diversified sources of supply. Furthermore, 
Korzinka has more than 4,400 employees, with monthly gross salaries of $216 for the lowest job 
category (administrative and junior roles), which is almost three times the minimum wage ($79).16 
Salaries were paid in full during the pandemic, thereby preserving the livelihoods of employees. 
Korzinka has adopted various COVID-19-related measures such as the provision of gloves, 
temperature checks, disinfection, and testing, and plans to increase the number of employees to 
6,000 (at an average pay of $240 for the above-mentioned positions) by 2023.  
 
10.  Strengthen women’s participation. The Uzbekistan labor market displays clear gender 
segregation by sector as women are highly represented in socially oriented sectors. The main 
forms of gender inequality are reported in discrimination in employment, dismissal, and career 
promotion.17 Female entrepreneurs are mostly involved in low-return service entrepreneurship 
and the vast majority of agri-business suppliers in Uzbekistan are businesses led by men.18 
Additionally, businesses led by women are disadvantaged when supplying to large companies,

3.  Borrower 
 
11.  Anglesey  Food  FE  LLC  (Korzinka)  was  incorporated  in  1996  and  is  domiciled  in 
Uzbekistan. Korzinka’s store formats include supermarkets, convenience stores, and discount 
stores offering more than 15,000 products including food and nonfood items (e.g., sanitary and 
hygiene  products,  cleaning  supplies,  paper,  and  kitchen  goods).  [Redacted]  Korzinka  is 
Uzbekistan’s leading modern grocery retailer with most stores located in Tashkent (80%) and the 
remaining in the regional centers (20%). In 2020, the EBRD joined as a minority shareholder to 
support expansion and corporatization.  
 
12.  Zafar Khashimov is the chief executive officer (CEO) and ultimate beneficiary owner. 
Anglesey Food FE LLC is a wholly owned subsidiary of Anglesey Investments Private Limited 
(incorporated in Singapore) [Redacted]. 
 
13.  As part of corporate governance reforms agreed with EBRD, the board of directors is 
composed  of  one  executive  and  three  nonexecutive  members.  Board  members  are  Zafar 
Khashimov (CEO), his brother Alisher Khashimov, Martin Elling (EBRD nominee), and Paul Foley 
(independent). Both, Martin Elling and Paul Foley have vast experience in retail in Europe and 
Central Asia. Board committees comprise audit, capital expenditure, compensation, and strategy.  
 
14.   Integrity due diligence. ADB conducted integrity due  diligence on Anglesey Food 
Foreign Enterprise LLC, Anglesey Investments, Marnell Holding, and on their boards of directors 
and managers.20 None of the companies or individuals appear to constitute a significant or 
potentially significant integrity risk to ADB. ADB’s review of the entities does not give ADB cause 
to believe that they have been established or are being used for money laundering or terrorism 
financing in the jurisdiction involved in the project.  
 
15.  Tax integrity due diligence. ADB conducted enhanced tax integrity due diligence.21 
Review of the entities does not give ADB cause to believe that the entities have been established 
or are being used for cross-border tax evasion in the jurisdictions involved in the project. The tax 
integrity and transparency risks are not significant and are acceptable to ADB.22  
B.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs  
 
16.  Impact. The project is aligned with the following impacts: industries, entrepreneurship, 
and employment of population supported during COVID-19 pandemic, and food security of 
population during pandemic ensured.

17.  Outcome. The outcome of the project will be the company’s scaled-up modern retail 
operations and improved workers' livelihoods. 
  
18.  Outputs. The outputs of the project are (i) procurement of inventories for modern retail 
operation increased, (ii) livelihoods of farmers secured in a gender-inclusive manner, and (iii) 
gender equality in employment opportunities and working conditions enhanced.  
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  
 
19.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project is aligned with 
Strategy 2030, which calls for ADB “to scale up its financing for agribusiness.”23 The project will 
be ADB’s first nonsovereign agribusiness transaction in Uzbekistan and is aligned with (i) the 
government’s strategy to diversify agricultural output towards high-value horticulture; and (ii) ADB 
country partnership strategy 2019–2023 for Uzbekistan, which targets financing “directly to 
bankable  private  sector  and  [state-owned  enterprise]  clients,  principally  in  the  financial, 
agribusiness, and infrastructure areas. Smaller-ticket transactions will be considered”.24 
 
20.  The  project  is  consistent  with  Strategy  2030’s  Operational  Plan  (OP)  for  priority  1 
(addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities) which calls for “generating quality jobs”, 
and OP for priority 5 (promoting rural development and food security), which calls for making an 
impact “in the fast-growing branded food, modern retail, and e-commerce sectors driven by the 
emergence  of  urban  middle  class.”25 It  is  aligned  with  Strategy  2030’s  OP  for  priority  2 
(accelerating progress in gender equality), which seeks to expand “operations in support of 
agribusiness value chains whereby women’s jobs and entrepreneurship opportunities will be 
enhanced in higher value-generating activities.”26 In addition, it is aligned with pillar 2 (regional 
trade and investment) of the OP for priority 7 and supports CAREC 2030 in Operational Cluster 
D by promoting regional trade in agriculture via Korzinka’s regional cross-border trade links.27 
 
21.  Consistency with sector strategy and relevant ADB operations. The project is aligned 
with ADB’s $20 billion COVID-19 response package, whereby ADB’s Private Sector Operations 
Department  focuses  on  financing  for  working capital  and  operating  expenditure  to  support 
continuity of operations of financially strong companies facing temporary liquidity issues because 
of the pandemic.28 The project is aligned with Operational Plan for Private Sector Operations, 
2019–2024, which identifies “food brands and food retail” as a priority segment because of the 
“potential to drive and structure upstream subsectors (e.g., on quality standards, traceability).”29

22.  Lessons from previous operations. The project builds on lessons learned from previous 
financings to relatively small companies with key person risk.30 First, the company is positioned 
downstream in the food value chain, which is a less risky segment than primary agricultural 
production. Second, the EBRD as a shareholder is leading corporate governance reforms, hence 
mitigating key person risk. Third, consistent with a risk appetite approach, the ticket size has been 
kept small given the size of the company and risks associated with the country. This deal selection 
and transaction structuring approach is consistent with the agribusiness strategy for smaller “Tier-
3” companies that are “leaders in their country or in their niche” (footnote 30).

III.  THE ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
25.  ADB will provide Korzinka a 3-year semi-annual amortizing (secured) local currency loan 
of $12,000,000 with 1-year grace period. The main terms and conditions of ADB’s proposed loan 
have been agreed with Korzinka. 
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
26.  ADB assistance will add value on three fronts: 
 
(i)  Access to medium-term financing. Korzinka has traditionally financed its term loans 
through two local commercial banks. Sum-denominated working capital loans are only 
available in short tenors of 12–18 months, which creates funding challenges. ADB’s 
financing will help Korzinka lower annual transaction costs and mitigate refinancing 
risk by providing financing over a longer planning horizon. 
(ii)  Diversified funding base. Lending terms offered by local banks are limited. During a 
significant devaluation of the sum in 2017, local banks only issued hard currency loans 
[Redacted]. ADB’s financing will provide appropriate local currency funding and help 
Korzinka diversify its funding sources. 
(iii) Gender inclusion. ADB will promote gender equality by working with Korzinka to 
implement a gender action plan to promote the inclusion of female suppliers, to 
address gender gaps in strategic managerial roles and at corporate level.33

provided by Korzinka and interviews with management staff. Korzinka is certified as ISO 9001 
and ISO 22000 and is currently preparing to apply for ISO 14001, ISO 45001, and ISO 50001 
certification,  and  recertification.  Thus,  most  policies  and  procedures  in  the  integrated 
management system either need to be developed or are being revised and amended. The 
environment, health, and safety management of Korzinka’s operations is under the supervision 
of the director general and the quality control department. The corporate audit observed gaps in 
Korzinka’s  environmental  and  social  policies  and  procedures.  Corrective  actions  were 
recommended to enhance the environment, health and safety, social, and labor policies and 
procedures and to strengthen institutional capacity. Detailed findings and corrective actions have 
been discussed and agreed. 
 
30.  The loan will not be used to fund any construction or expansion of physical assets which 
involve activities that include permanent or temporary land acquisition; any retrofit, rehabilitation, 
or expansion projects; or any activities that may directly or indirectly affect indigenous peoples or 
vulnerable ethnic minorities. Nevertheless, Korzinka’s processes were reviewed, and it was 
established that Korzinka acquires assets on a willing buyer, willing seller basis. The project 
activities are likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts. 
 
31.  Korzinka will apply ADB’s prohibited investment activities list, comply with the Safeguard 
Policy Statement, and abide by national laws and regulations. Korzinka will comply with national 
labor laws and, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy (2001), will take measures to comply 
with international core labor standards. It will report regularly to ADB on compliance with such 
laws, and measures taken. Information disclosure and consultation with affected people, if 
needed, will be conducted in accordance with ADB requirements.35 
 
32.  Effective  gender  mainstreaming.  The  project  is  classified  as  effective  gender 
mainstreaming. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development, Korzinka has incorporated 
measures to promote gender equality and women’s empowerment in its business activities.36 Key 
features of the gender action plan include (i) recommendations by Korzinka on gender-responsive 
practices in food staple supply chains to a portion of its large suppliers, (ii) integration of female 
suppliers in Korzinka´s value chains, (iii) staffing target of women in store management positions, 
(iv)  participation  of  skills-based  female  staff  in  a  tailored  leadership  training  program,  (v) 
establishment of a women’s network to steer career development, and (vi) increased awareness 
of staff on sexual harassment and on Korzinka’s policies on this issue. Korzinka will submit 
periodic reports on implementation of its gender action plan to ADB. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
33.  Korzinka was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating 
to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that 
the loan documentation includes appropriate provisions prohibiting corruption, money laundering, 
and the financing of terrorism and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
 
35 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).   
36 ADB. 1998. Policy on Gender and Development. Manila. 
 
PUBLIC. This information is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information Policy.

9 
C.  Investment Limitations 
 
[Redacted]  
 
D.  Assurances 
 
34.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),37 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that  the Government of 
Uzbekistan has no objection to the proposed assistance to Korzinka. ADB will enter into suitable 
finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
35.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$12,000,000 (in sum equivalent) from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to Anglesey Food Foreign 
Enterprise LLC (Korzinka) for the Korzinka COVID-19 Food Retail Supply Chain Support Project 
in Uzbekistan, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board.  
 
Masatsugu Asakawa
